The following are symbols that you will encounter in this course.  They are ordered by roughly the order in which you will encounter the symbol.

<div class="container">
<dl class="dl-horizontal">
<dt>n</dt><dd>- Sample size.</dd>
<dt>N</dt><dd>- Population size.</dd>
<dt>$\bar{x}$</dt><dd>- Sample mean (average) of the X variable.</dd>
<dt>&mu;</dt><dd>- Population mean.</dd>
<dt>s</dt><dd>- Sample standard deviation.</dd>
<dt>&sigma;</dt><dd>- Population standard deviation.</dd>
<dt>s<sup>2</sup></dt><dd>- Sample variance.</dd>
<dt>Q1</dt><dd>- First quartile.</dd>
<dt>Q3</dt><dd>- Third quartile.</dd>
<dt>IQR</dt><dd>- Interquartile range (Q3-Q1).</dd>
<dt>X~N(&mu;,&sigma;)</dt><dd>- The variable X is normally distributioned with a mean of &mu; and standard deviation of &sigma;.</dd>
<dt>N(0,1)</dt><dd>- Standard normal distribution.</dd>
<dt>Z</dt><dd>- (i) A variable that follows a N(0,1).  (ii) The test statistic in a one-sample Z-test.</dd>
<dt>r</dt><dd>- (i) The sample correlation coefficient.  (ii) The number of rows in a two-way frequency table.</dd>
<dt>c</dt><dd>- The number of columns in a two-way frequency table.</dd>
<dt></dt><dd>- </dd>


<dt>&alpha;</dt><dd>- (i) The rejection criterion.  (ii) The probability of making a Type I error.</dd>
<dt>&beta;</dt><dd>- The probability of making a Type II error.</dd>
<dt>M</dt><dd>- The sample median.</dd>
